 But for a parent that loves their child and wants to teach them right from wrong, spanking is a tool of discipline.
 
 -Example one: Johnny hits Tommy.
 I feel that these are the proper steps of discipline:
 1st offense: Tell Johnny that it is wrong to hit Tommy, seperate him and Tommy for a few days. Do not just discipline Johnny but talk to him and tell him why it is wrong. Make sure he know not to hit, because it is wrong, not just because he will get spanked. Warn him that next time he will lose a privledge.
 
 2nd offense: Tell Johnny again that it is wrong, and take away a privledge, so that he knows there are consequences. Warn him that next time he will get a spanking.
 
 3rd offense: Tell Johnny that it is wrong, and follow up with the previous warning of a spanking.
 
 -Example two: Katie colors on the white wall with red and black crayons.
 1st offense: Tell Katie it is wrong and tell her she can only have her crayons when Mom or Dad is there to watch her. Warn her that next time she will get her crayons taken away.
 2nd offense: Tell Katie it is wrong and take away her crayons.
 Warn her that next time she will get a spanking.
 3rd offense: Tell Katie that it is wrong, and follow up with the previous warning of spanking.
 
 It is wrong to just spank a child without explaining what he/she did wrong. Children are people too, and they need to know what they did wrong so they will learn not to do it again. This way, children will not learn to fear the parents wrath, but they will learn right from wrong. 
 Give the children a discipline system based on consequences, and follow up with it. Do not threaten a child with a spanking if they mis-behave at their freinds house. Tell them that they will not get to see their friend, and if it happens again, promise them a spanking, and follow through.
 The biggest mistake of disciplining a child is failure to follow through. If the consequences is spanking, then by golly, spank them. Because if you don't, they will learn that they can get away with it, because mom and dad never follow through.

Hank and Gilligan, I have to agree with the both of you. Like you, Gilligan, I had an occasion every now and then were I 'deserved a spankin'. I'm sure all of us have had those moments. When parents sit down and try to talk to little children and explain to them what they did wrong, there's very little chance that they are actually comprehending anything that is being said to them. If they do comprehend, then I doubt they're of the majority. This is simply because they're young. Spanking is simple, and if done properly (sounds funny....) then it does its job. Punishment (as I learned in psychology...) has to occur immediately after the 'crime' is committed. Otherwise it does no good. The phrase "you'll hear about this later' is almost a joke to me... it simply doesn't do much good.

Also, the child is not going to learn from it, and may become 'immune' to it. (not to the point where they don't notice pain, but where they fail to associate pain with punishment)

If a child runs out onto the road, it has just used its one and only chance, and no amount of modelling good behaviour is going to help it. Fear and apprehension, as archaic and incorrect as it sounds, must be taught instead.
 
 Also, it is very difficult to model non-behaviour. It is easy to model how to do something the correct way, or how to do the right thing, but not easy to model how to not do something. Positive reinforcers are better than negative ones, but not always applicable. For example, how do you positively reward a child for not beating his peers? At some point children become mostly independent, making their own choices.  Personal story: My mother was spanked as a child, and lived in fear of her father. She usually did what he said to his face but covertly disobeyed him because her fear was of being punished, not acting wrong. When she had her own kids, she had an experience which made her want to do differently than her parents.
 
 My older sister was just a baby at the time, sitting on my mother's left knee in the living room of a friend they were visiting. My sister kept pulling at a house plant that was beside her in the corner of the room. My mother smacked her hand (she was concerned the plant might be poisonous), and my sister looked shocked, and started to cry. She was completely distracted from the plant while she was crying, but as soon as she recovered she reached for the plant again. My mother had a sort of epiphany that this wasn't working very well, and she should think about what she was doing instead of just automatically doing what her parents did. She moved my sister to her right knee, and handed her a toy. Problem solved.

Not just your conjecture and what you think the reason is, but rather hard statistical studies that support your claim. I think you will not find any. I have actually looked for it.
 
 
 Epaphras_faith, It is plain common sense. If you remove a child from a situation, and they do not fully understand why they were removed, what stops the child from repeating that same behaviour again? Maybe the next time the child does repeat the behaviour, a parent might not reach the child in time to stop an accident. I am unsure why statistical evidence is needed for you to understand this.

That statement, from an anti-spanking advocate, seems to fly directly in the face of your own arguement epaphras_faith.)

 ("Dr. Baumrind described findings from her own research, an analysis of data from a long-term study of more than 100 families, indicating that mild to moderate spanking had no detrimental effects when such confounding influences were separated out. And the few that remained could be explained by other aspects of the parent-child relationship. " "When parents are loving and firm and communicate well with the child," Dr. Baumrind said, "the children are exceptionally competent and well adjusted, whether or not their parents spanked them as preschoolers." ) **** You have to agree with me now epaphras_faith, becuase you place so much emphasis on the findings of psychologists, and this lady is contridicting you. **** Dr. Straus, who attended Dr. Baumrind's talk, praised her study. "It may be the best single study available," he said, in terms of methodology. Even anti-spanking advocates liked what she had to say.
 
 
 The point, that I belive has been clearly made here, is that the studies that you rely so heavily on to support your arguements and believe provide the unoquivically correct answers, appear to not hold the answer to this debate. When I searched the web for studies on spanking, there were multiple studies that supported both sides, so which of the studies do we belive and which do we disregard?

You have to deny the evidence.
